ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Severe Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Primary complaint of severe sound intolerance; collapsed LDLs (20-30 dB HL for tones); catastrophic impact on life.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Tinnitus
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral, reactive tinnitus with abrupt onset; TFI 83 and THI 84 indicate catastrophic handicap.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: High-Frequency Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Mild-to-moderate loss at 8000 Hz; moderate-to-severe ultra-high-frequency loss (9-14 kHz).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Anxiety Disorder / Phonophobia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Symptoms consistent with DSM-5 criteria for anxiety; fear of sounds (phonophobia); significant weight loss due to fear of eating sounds.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To quantify the functional impact of tinnitus and hyperacusis (TFI, THI).
To assess hearing sensitivity above 8000 Hz, often relevant in tinnitus/hyperacusis.
To quantify sound tolerance levels and confirm hyperacusis.
To characterize tinnitus pitch, loudness, maskability, and residual inhibition.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial ENT evaluation revealed normal hearing sensitivity through the mid-frequencies with a high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss at 8000 Hz. Word recognition was excellent.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds 250-6000 Hz (Left) and 250-4000 Hz (Right); mild-to-moderate SNHL at 8000 Hz (40-50 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent word recognition (100% at 40 dB HL) bilaterally; SRT 0 dB HL.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Comprehensive evaluation confirmed severe hyperacusis with collapsed loudness discomfort levels and catastrophic tinnitus distress. Ultra-high-frequency testing showed significant loss extended beyond 8 kHz.

tests.name: Ultra-high-frequency audiometry
tests.result_summary: Moderate-to-severe loss 9-14 kHz; no response >14 kHz.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.result_summary: Significantly reduced: 45-55 dB HL for speech, 20-30 dB HL for pure tones (500-4000 Hz).

tests.name: Tinnitus Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Pitch/loudness match completed; residual inhibition stopped at 24s due to discomfort.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Not completed due to reported sound intolerance and reactive tinnitus.

proposed_items: Sound therapy using a phone app to replace ear protection
Combined approach of desensitization and sound therapy due to severity
counseling_actions: Explained difference between hyperacusis and hearing loss
Explained the tinnitus/hyperacusis cycle and neurophysiological model
Advised to reduce use of ear protection in quiet to minimize avoidance
Discussed role of anxiety and stress in exacerbating symptoms
Addressed patient's misunderstanding regarding lymphatic system involvement

escalation.destination: Primary Care Physician and Mental Health Professional
escalation.rationale_short: Referral needed for significant weight loss, sleep disturbance, anxiety, and new somatic symptoms (numbing/tingling).

follow_up_plan.timeline: Ongoing email communication over several weeks
follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor response to sound therapy and desensitization; address worsening psychological and somatic symptoms.

expected_outcome: Patient reported initial relief from utilizing sound therapy in place of ear protection.
Patient reported persistent sleeping difficulties despite initial management.
One week later, symptoms (hyperacusis, reactive tinnitus, anxiety) worsened exponentially with new explicit fear of sounds (phonophobia).
Patient reported new numbing and tingling sensations in face accompanying offensive sounds.
